Fe3O4@SiO2@(CH2)3-urea-thiourea: A novel hydrogen-bonding and reusable catalyst for the construction of bipyridine-5-carbonitriles via a cooperative vinylogous anomeric based oxidation Fatemeh Karimi Methodology Validation Investigation Writing - original draft Meysam Yarie Methodology Validation Investigation Writing - original draft Mohammad Ali Zolfigol Supervision Resources Project administration Funding acquisition Conceptualization Writing - review & editing * Department of Organic Chemistry, Faculty of Chemistry, Bu-Ali Sina University, Hamedan 6517838683, Iran Department of Organic Chemistry Faculty of Chemistry Bu-Ali Sina University Hamedan 6517838683 Iran ⁎ Corresponding author. Graphical abstract The proficiency of Fe3O4@SiO2@(CH2)3-urea-thiourea as a novel H-bonding and reusable nanomagnetic catalyst successfully probed through the multicomponent synthesis of bipyridine-5-carbonitriles via a cooperative vinylogous anomeric based oxidation mechanism under solvent free conditions. Fe3O4@SiO2@(CH2)3-urea-thiourea as a new hydrogen-bonding and retrievable nanomagnetic catalyst was fabricated and its structure confirmed by transmission electron microscopy (TEM), thermogravimetric analysis/ derivative thermogravimetric (TGA/DTG), vibrating sample magnetometer (VSM), Fourier transform infrared (FT-IR) spectroscopy, field emission scanning electron microscopy (FESEM), energy dispersive spectroscopy (EDS), and elemental mapping analysis. The catalytic performance of the novel hydrogen-bonding catalyst was appropriately probed through the multicomponent preparation of bipyridine-5-carbonitriles via a cooperative vinylogous anomeric based oxidation (CVABO) mechanism in the absence of any solvent. The novel hydrogen-bonding nanomagnetic catalyst can readily be regained and reused four times without appreciable destruction of catalytic efficiency. Keywords Anomeric effect Bipyridine-5-carbonitriles Cooperative vinylogous anomeric based oxidation Fe3O4@SiO2@(CH2)3-urea-thiourea Hydrogen-bonding catalyst Multicomponent reactions 1 Introduction A privileged scaffold of N-heterocycles found in functional materials, natural compounds and products with particular pharmaceutical applications is pyridine nucleus [1–7]. Among these compounds, cyanopyridines have been well-known to possess analgesic [8], anticonvulsant [8], antihypertensive [9,10], antipyretic [11], anti-inﬂammatory [11,12] and antitumor [13] properties. Also, bipyridines as an important subset of pyridines are applied as building blocks in supramolecular chemistry, chelating ligands in coordination chemistry, light-emitting diodes, molecular electronics, metal-containing polymers, solar cells, photo-activated species, and as optoelectronic devices [14–18]. Moreover, bipyridines and related complexes have also found numerous applications in polymer and dendrimer science [19–21], asymmetric catalysis [22,23], artificial photosynthesis [24], and photoinduced electron transfer [25,26]. Increase the atomic economy and the efficiency of chemical reactions, reduce derivatives, waste generation and utilization of organic solvents, simplifying the corresponding processes and design for energy efficiency are most important principles of green chemistry which multicomponent reactions (MCRs) are in good accordance with them. These types of reactions as a robust protocol for development of large chemical libraries of drug-like compounds have been nominated and expanded [27–34]. Nanomagnetic catalyst due to their high specific surface area and simple separation from the reaction mixture exhibited high catalytic performance and recyclability in various organic syntheses. Other merits of the nanomagnetic catalyst are biocompatibility and possibility of modification the surface of magnetic nanoparticles with both of organic and inorganic compounds. These unique features have led to a growing concern in the preparation and applications of heterogeneous types of catalysts among the academic and industrial scientists [35–39]. Hydrogen-bonding as one of the main non-covalent interactions is responsible for the unusual properties of bulk water, the fidelity of DNA base pairing and the three-dimensional structures of proteins. Also, hydrogen-bonding performs a decisive functional responsibility in catalysis to the extent that hydrogen-bonding donors can be used as general acid catalysts for different kinds of reactions in organic chemistry [40–46]. Therefore, much effort has been directed towards the detection of numerous kinds of hydrogen-bonding donors such as phosphoric acids, diols and ureas/thioureas [47–56]. Recently, we have comprehensively reviewed various aspects of urea and its derivatives as powerful and influential catalytic active agents in a wide range of chemical processes [57]. The anomeric effect as a stereoelectronic phenomenon [58–66] has a potent impression to elucidate some peculiar phenomena in chemistry. For example, this concept can explain the preference of the gauche conformer of hydrazine than the anti one. This preference originates from stabilizing effects of anomeric interactions between non-bonding lone pair electrons of nitrogen atoms and vacant anti-bonding orbitals of NH bonds (n N→σ*N-H) [67]. These stabilizing effects are absent in the anti conformer (Scheme 1 ). Also, more stability of Z-isomer in esters than E-isomer is associated with anomeric nO→ σ*C-O interactions in which in-plan lone pairs of oxygen can donate into the σ*C-O orbital of the carbonyl moiety (Scheme 2 ) [68]. The vinylogous anomeric effect (VAE) is a type of anomeric effect which had been extended through double bonds and had been employed for the stereoelectronic supported interaction of unshared electron pairs to a vacant anti-bonding sigma orbital (n→σ*) over four bonds [69–77]. This term can easily clarify the cushy loss of benzotriazole group in compounds A and B (Scheme 3 ) [69]. Nowadays "cooperative anomeric and/or vinylogous anomeric based oxidation" demonstrate a novel mechanistic path for the oxidative aromatization of wide susceptible intermediates in the course of heterocycles synthesis. These concepts have been also reviewed by one of us [78,79]. In this paper, we wish to develop the term of cooperative vinylogous anomeric-based oxidation (CVABO) [80–86] and in pursuance of our research to develop new protocols for the synthesis of pyridine derivatives [78,79,81–88] and catalysts bearing urea moiety [57,86,88–91]. With this aim, herein design, synthesis, characterization and catalytic behaviour of Fe3O4@SiO2@(CH2)3-urea-thiourea as a novel hydrogen-bonding and retrievable catalyst in construction of bipyridine-5-carbonitriles via VABO pathway was presented (Schemes 4 and 5 ). 2 Experimental 2.1 General procedure for the preparation of 2-carbamothionyl-N-(3-(triethoxysilyl)propyl)hydrazinecarboxamide (Ligand A) Initially, ligand A was prepared via the reaction of thiosemicarbazide (5.0 mmol, 0.456 g) and triethoxy(3-isocyanatopropyl)silane (5.0 mmol, 1.237 g) in the absence of any solvent at 60 °C for 6 h. Afterwards, the result product washed with the mixture of n-hexane and dichloromethane (10:1) (3 × 10 mL) to furnish ligand A (Scheme 4). 2.2 General procedure for the synthesis of hydrogen-bonding nanomagnetic catalyst Fe3O4@SiO2@(CH2)3-urea-thiourea The preparation of Fe3O4 nanoparticles was reported before [92]. Afterwards, Fe3O4 nanoparticles were reacted with tetraethyl orthosilicate (TEOS) to form Fe3O4@SiO2. Then, Fe3O4@SiO2 (1.0 g) was reacted with ligand A (3.0 mmol, 1.014 g) under refluxing toluene for 48 h to give final catalyst Fe3O4@SiO2@(CH2)3-urea-thiourea (Scheme 4). 2.3 General procedure for the construction of bipyridine-5-carbonitriles A mixture of aromatic aldehyde (1.0 mmol), acetylpyridine (1.0 mmol, 0.121 g), ethylcyanoacetate (1.0 mmol, 0.113 g), ammonium acetate (2.0 mmol, 0.154 g) and 10 mg of Fe3O4@SiO2@(CH2)3-urea-thiourea was stirred at 100 °C for enough time in the neat conditions (Table 2). After completion of the reactions, as checked by TLC (ethylacetate : n-hexane (1:1)), it was diluted with hot CH2Cl2 and the catalyst separated by utilizing an external magnet. Finally, the solvent was evaporated. The crude solids obtained were triturated using hot ethanol, filtered off and washed successively with ethanol. The obtained solid was dried and crystallized from methanol to give desired pure bipyridine-5-carbonitrile derivatives in high yields (Table 2). 2.4 Selected spectral data 2.4.1 2-Carbamothionyl-N-(3-(triethoxysilyl)propyl)hydrazinecarboxamide (ligand A) A white solid, Melting point: 149–151 °C FT-IR (KBr): ν (cm−1): 3348, 3244, 3186, 2972, 2938, 2884, 1678, 1621, 1610, 1547, 1515, 1269, 1104. 1H NMR (300 MHz, DMSO, δ, ppm): 9.05 (s, 1H, NH), 7.91 (s, 2H, NH2), 6.26 (s, 1H, NH), 4.51 (s, 1H, NH), 3.75 (q, 6H, J = 6 Hz, CH2O), 3.02−2.96 (m, 2H, J = 6 Hz, CH2), 1.45 (qintet, 2H, J = 6 Hz, CH2), 1.15 (t, 9H, J = 6 Hz, CH3), 0.66−0.61 (m, 2H, CH2Si). 13C NMR (76 MHz, DMSO, δ, ppm): 181.6, 157.9, 58.2, 42.5, 23.7, 18.7, 7.6. So, the existence of more than one donor with suitable orientation to an acceptor is critical. Finding susceptible systems for cooperative anomeric effect interactions are our main research interest. Such systems are interesting because the joint effect of multiple interactions can explain unusual reactivity of a typical molecule with more than one donor orbitals. To the best of our knowledge, many biological processes involve oxidation-reduction of substrates by NAD+/NADH respectively [93–97]. The key feature of the oxidation mechanism is hydride transfer from carbon via stereoelectronic interactions (Scheme 6 ). Thus development of stereoelectronic effects lead to knowledge based designing of new biomimetic reactions. Therefore, we decided to develop the term of “anomeric based oxidation (ABO)” via the catalytic synthesis of bipyridine-5-carbonitriles. 3.1 Characterization of Fe3O4@SiO2@(CH2)3-urea-thiourea After the successful preparation of Fe3O4@SiO2@(CH2)3-urea-thiourea, the structure of nanomagnetic catalyst was elucidated using TEM, FESEM, elemental mapping analysis, EDS, VSM, FT-IR spectroscopy and TGA/DTG. The FT-IR spectrum of Fe3O4@SiO2@(CH2)3-urea-thiourea has been compared with a) Fe3O4, b)Fe3O4@SiO2 and c) ligand A in Fig. 1 . The overall changes upon coating each layer confirmed successful preparation of the new nanomagnetic catalyst. In FT‐IR spectrum of Fe3O4@SiO2@(CH2)3-urea-thiourea, all anticipated functional groups including NH (3289 cm−1), CO (1674 cm−1), CN (1614 cm−1) and Si-O (1084 cm−1) are clearly detectable. As depicted in Fig. 2 , EDS spectrum reveals the presence of Fe, O, Si, C, N, and S elements in the synthesized nanocatalyst. Also, these results confirmed by obtained results from the elemental mapping analysis as emerged in Fig. 3 . The morphology and size of Fe3O4@SiO2@(CH2)3-urea-thiourea was investigated by FESEM images. Based on these FESEM images, the sizes of the catalyst particles are lower than 20 nm (Fig. 4 ). Also, the obtained TEM micrographs of Fe3O4@SiO2@(CH2)3-urea-thiourea demonstrate the nano sized structure of particles and are in good conformity with the FESEM images of the novel catalyst (Fig. 5 ). The magnetic property of Fe3O4@SiO2@(CH2)3-urea-thiourea was considered by using a vibrating sample magnetometer (VSM). As showed in Fig. 6 , the value of magnetic saturation for novel catalyst is about 27.14 emu g−1. Thus, the novel hydrogen-bonding catalyst can be efficiently isolated using of an external magnetic bar. Fig. 7 express the achieved TGA and DTG analysis curves of Fe3O4@SiO2@(CH2)3-urea-thiourea. The weight loss upon heating from ambient temperature up to 236 °C can be ascribed to the evaporation of organic solvents and water which were used for the preparation of novel catalyst. Also, the weight loss from 236 to 505 °C can be ascribed to the decomposition of organic layer coated on the surface of Fe3O4 nanoparticles (weight loss of about 36.14 %). Based on the achieved data, the Fe3O4@SiO2@(CH2)3-urea-thiourea shows high thermal stability upon the investigated reaction. 3.2 Application of the novel hydrogen-bonding catalyst in the synthesis of bipyridine-5-carbonitrile derivatives After the full characterization of the synthesized catalyst with suitable techniques, the catalytic utility of Fe3O4@SiO2@(CH2)3-urea-thiourea was tested in the multicomponent synthesis of bipyridine-5-carbonitrile derivatives. The initial attempt was guided by the model reaction between of benzaldehyde, 4-acetylpyridine, ethylcyanoacetate, and ammonium acetate. Effects of different parameters such as amount of temperature, catalyst, as well as the solvent effects are investigated on the overall yield and time of the reaction. Based on the obtained data in Table 1 , 10 mg catalyst at 100 °C in the absence of any solvent determined to be the optimum reaction conditions (Table 1, entry 2). Also, in order to confirm the last step of the suggested mechanism of reaction, it was performed under nitrogen and argon atmospheres and in the optimized conditions. The achieved results in all atmospheres are similar (Table 1, entry 2). Then, the substrate scope and generality of the presented protocol evaluated by applying different arylaldehydes, acetylpyridine (2, 3 and 4-isomers), ethylcyanoacetate and ammonium acetate in the presence of Fe3O4@SiO2@(CH2)3-urea-thiourea as a retrievable catalyst under the optimized reaction conditions. As illustrated in Table 2 , all desired products were synthesized in short times with high to excellent yields. 3.3 Catalyst recycling and reusing test In a separate study, the recycling test of Fe3O4@SiO2@(CH2)3-urea-thiourea was probed by a model reaction between benzaldehyde, 4-acetylpyridine, ethylcyanoacetate and ammonium acetate. After each run, addition of hot CH2Cl2 to the reaction mixture, caused dissolving the components and collection of Fe3O4@SiO2@(CH2)3-urea-thiourea using a simple magnetic bar. Then, it washed with CH2Cl2, dried, weighted and reused for the subsequent run. As depicted in Fig. 8 , it can be inferred that the catalyst has elegant recovery capability for reusing test. A suggested mechanism for the synthesis of bipyridin 5-carbonitriles using Fe3O4@SiO2@(CH2)3-urea-thiourea via a cooperative vinylogous anomeric based oxidation (CVABO) pathway portrayed in Scheme 7 for the desired molecule 1a as a model reaction. At first, in the presence of novel catalyst, the enamine intermediate A produced by the reaction of 4-acetylpyridine and ammonium acetate, attacked intermediate B (generated from the condensation benzaldehyde and ethylcyanoacetate) to yield intermediate C. Afterwards, intermolecular nucleophilic attack of nitrogen atom in intermediate C, produced compound D by anomeric effect supporting and releasing one molecule of ethanol. Finally, via a cooperative vinylogous anomeric based oxidation CVABO mechanism, target molecule 1a is produced through unusual hydride transfer for release of molecular hydrogen (H2). The achieved data from optimization of described reaction under argon and nitrogen atmospheres verified our suggestion for oxidation and aromatization of intermediate D [78,79]. 4 Conclusions In conclusions, we have designed, prepared and fully characterized Fe3O4@SiO2@(CH2)3-urea-thiourea as a new Hydrogen-bonding and retrievable catalyst with magnetic properties. The catalytic performance of titled catalyst was appropriately explored in the multicomponent construction of bipyridine-5-carbonitriles upon the reaction of aromatic aldehydes, acetylpyridine (2, 3 and 4-isomers), ethylcyanoacetate and ammonium acetate via a CVABO mechanism under solvent free conditions. The obtained biological based bipyridine-5-carbonitrile compounds are suitable candidates for the biological studies. The key feature of the described oxidation mechanism is hydride transfer from carbon via “anomeric based oxidation” (ABO). Thus the described stereoelectronic effects lead to knowledge based designing of biomimetic reactions in the future.The attractive features of this procedure are a simple procedure, solvent free conditions, high to excellent yields of target molecules, brief reaction time, easy work-up procedure, mild reaction conditions and use of a nanomagnetic catalyst with good reversibility. coredata.dc:description: Fe3O4@SiO2@(CH2)3-urea-thiourea as a new hydrogen-bonding and retrievable nanomagnetic catalyst was fabricated and its structure confirmed by transmission electron microscopy (TEM), thermogravimetric analysis/ derivative thermogravimetric (TGA/DTG), vibrating sample magnetometer (VSM), Fourier transform infrared (FT-IR) spectroscopy, field emission scanning electron microscopy (FESEM), energy dispersive spectroscopy (EDS), and elemental mapping analysis. The catalytic performance of the novel hydrogen-bonding catalyst was appropriately probed through the multicomponent preparation of bipyridine-5-carbonitriles via a cooperative vinylogous anomeric based oxidation (CVABO) mechanism in the absence of any solvent. The novel hydrogen-bonding nanomagnetic catalyst can readily be regained and reused four times without appreciable destruction of catalytic efficiency.
coredata.dc:title: Fe3O4@SiO2@(CH2)3-urea-thiourea: A novel hydrogen-bonding and reusable catalyst for the construction of bipyridine-5-carbonitriles via a cooperative vinylogous anomeric based oxidation
